message: Thanks to all who expressed outrage against the attempted gutting of the House ethics office. They backed down!

Protecting the gains made under the Affordable Care Act is in the interest of all Americans. But many in the GOP want to repeal the ACA without a replacement, which would leave millions without coverage, cause premiums to skyrocket for the rest, and damage local hospitals. President Obama spoke with Democratic members of the House and Senate today to get us fired up and ready to go for this fight.

Partners in the fight to preserve the Affordable Care Act sent a powerful message to the #GOP today: We will #ProtectOurCare. My fellow Pro-Choice Caucus Co-Chair Louise Slaughter, House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi, Cecile Richards of Planned Parenthood,  Ilyse Hogue of NARAL and other members of the Pro-Choice Caucus joined me in reminding Republicans of the injustices women faced in the years before the ACA that severely limited our access to fair and affordable health coverage. We can’t let Republicans turn back the clock. I want all women, and men who care about women, who are worried right now about this issue to know that we are fighting for you. Women deserve more than this from Congress. Make your voices heard

At our #ProtectOurCare event yesterday, I was honored to lead an incredible group of speakers, including the presidents of NARAL and Planned Parenthood, in calling on Republicans to keep their hands off of the #ACA and preserve the fair and affordable coverage that the law has ensured for millions of women. Watch this video and join us in the fight!

The Affordable Care Act is more than a law, it’s a lifeline for millions of people across the country. As Republicans prepare to repeal the #ACA, let’s let them know exactly what they’ll be taking away from Coloradans. Tell me how the ACA has benefited you or your family right here on my Facebook page with the hashtag #ProtectOurCareCO.

Many of you have questions about what the changes in Washington mean for you and your families. I’ll do my best to answer them in a #FacebookLive Q&A next Tuesday at 4 p.m. MT. To kick off this important discussion, write your policy-related questions below; you can also chime in during the chat. I’m excited to connect with you. Please note that this page is an official resource, not affiliated with any campaign, and therefore questions about upcoming elections are not permissible.

I’m honored today to join the House Committee on Energy and Commerce subcommittees on the Environment and Health, as well as to continue serving as the top Democrat on the Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee. We’ll cover issues affecting everyday life in Colorado and our country’s long-term future. I’ll work across the political aisle whenever possible to ensure that we’re headed in the right direction, but I also won’t shy away from a fight – the stakes are too high.

This #MLKDay, the march towards fairness and equality continues – but we have come a long way. Despite setbacks, we will fight even harder, knowing that we have love and light on our side. Dr. King put it best: “The arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends towards justice.”

This morning I did a live interview on C-SPAN’s Washington Journal, taking viewer calls and engaging in a spirited discussion about the dramatic costs of #ACA repeal – and what we’re doing to fight it. Watch here, and let me know what you think.
Today's the day! Join us to protest the heedless rush to repeal the Affordable Care Act.
Our First Stand. Rally to save the #ProtectOurCare

Thank you so much to the nearly 500 constituents who turned out today to protest the reckless rush toward repealing the Affordable Care Act. It was especially touching that so many of you stood outside to listen on loudspeakers since we'd filled every seat n the house!  Rep. Ed Perlmutter, Lt. Gov. Donna Lynne, Speaker Crisanta Duran and SEIU Local President Ron Ruggiero really got the crowd fired up. That's what we need -- we may be in for a long fight.
NA

Our community was infused with the spirit of #MLK as we gathered for Denver’s annual #Marade. We still need to draw strength and inspiration from Dr. King’s work to ensure equal rights and civil liberties for everyone. He faced unimaginable adversity and paid the highest price, but succeeded in changing our nation and our world through the power of principle. We can protect and advance his legacy if we stand united in the values we hold dear.

Join me for a #FacebookLive Q&A TODAY at 4 p.m. MT. After a big weekend rallying to prevent repeal of the #ACA, I’m excited to answer questions about how this step and other proposed changes in Washington will affect you and your families. Submit your questions in advance in the comments below or ask them live via the chat. Please note that this page is an official resource, not affiliated with any campaign, and therefore questions about upcoming elections are not permissible.
Starting now: join us for a FB Live Q&A. Please type your questions below.
NA

Thank you to all who joined our Facebook Live Q&A today, submitting questions in advance or during the chat. It was a good conversation. Apologies to those who experienced technical difficulties; we look forward to connecting with you more smoothly in the future.

“It was a joy visiting my alma mater, Denver South High School, to engage with a diverse group of students about what a Trump presidency means for their future. Understandably, many are worried about the recent rise nationwide of hate speech and anti-immigrant sentiment, along with proposed changes to immigration and refugee policy. I wanted them to know that I will continue fighting hard to ensure that all students in this country are able to realize their dreams. Thanks to these bright kids for sharing their perspectives during this enlightening and uplifting visit.

#WomenAreWatching, President-elect Trump. That’s why Louise Slaughter and I are sending you a letter, signed by 174 House members, urging you to be a president who values women in policy and principle. We ask that you reconsider plans to repeal the #ACA, defund Planned Parenthood and strip away our reproductive rights. The women (and men who care about women) of this country won’t stand for it. We suggest you read this letter carefully.

Saturday’s #WomensMarch is an experience I will never forget. I hit the streets of DC with half a million others, including an estimated 2,000 Coloradans, to advocate for reproductive rights, equal pay, affordable health care, social justice and more. Our calls were echoed by people in rallies around the world, including an estimated 100,000 in Denver. It should now be clear to President Trump that #WomenAreWatching, and we will hold him and his administration accountable.
#TrumpGlobalGag signing today proves yet again how long the road ahead will be to reach gender equality. #WomenAreWatching

Today the House of Representatives passed #HR7, the “No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion and Abortion Insurance Full Disclosure Act of 2017,”  by a vote of 238-183, with just three Democrats supporting it. I led the debate on the House floor against this extreme bill, which will further limit access to abortion for millions of women. These restrictions against federal funding, imposed year after year through the Hyde Amendment, deny reproductive services to low-income women, who often need them the most. I have long opposed Hyde, co-sponsoring the EACH Woman Act, which would end this unfair policy once and for all. While this bill’s passage in the House is dismaying, it’s likely that the Senate will again stop it.  And I will continue fighting against the GOP’s extreme, anti-choice agenda because women are worth it.

So sad to hear of the passing of my friend #MaryTylerMoore, a tireless advocate for diabetes prevention through the JDRF, embryonic stem cell research and an inspiration to every young girl with big dreams. I’ll always remember your wise words: "Take chances, make mistakes. That's how you grow. Pain nourishes your courage. You have to fail in order to practice being brave.” You may no longer be with us, but you’ll continue to turn the world on with your smile.

‎I condemn in the strongest terms the two executive orders issued by the President Trump today. They will roll back progress on immigration policy that our country has made during the past eight years.   Notably, these orders would reinstate the Secure Communities program that Colorado has already tried and soundly rejected. They direct the Department of Homeland Security not only to build a wall we don't need, but also to build more detention centers and hold individuals there in violation of their due process rights.  And they threaten to withhold federal funds from any jurisdiction that doesn't agree with the new draconian policies, putting millions of dollars for Colorado in question.  President Trump's orders today do not reflect long-held American values. They do not reflect Colorado values. Over the last few years, as fear of immigrants and refugees has increased in some places, Coloradans have pulled together and made ‎clear that we will not be divided. While saddened by this day, I know we will come together again as a community and do what is right.

Thanks to the more than 200 Coloradans who attended my listening session on saving the Affordable Care Act. Your stories about what this coverage means for you and your families inspired and energized our continued efforts to stop a reckless repeal by President Trump and the GOP. The #ACA is more than a law: It’s a lifeline that has allowed millions to achieve health, quality of life and peace of mind. We won’t give it up without a fight. If you were unable to attend last night’s event, you can share your stories on my Facebook page with the hashtag #ProtectOurCareCO. I’d love to hear from you.
Under the plan announced yesterday, every American will be paying for President Trump's wall whether we like it or not. #Trumponomics
NA

President Trump's executive order on refugees slammed the door to safety, security and hope for millions around the world. America has always been a beacon to oppressed people, and while this extreme policy is a major setback, it doesn't change America's inclusive spirit. Can President Trump look refugees like Omran Daqneesh, the Syrian boy in this photo, in the eye and say they’re not welcome? Could anyone with a conscience?

Lots of #AlternativeFacts have been used to support the repeal of the #ACA, but in today’s Denver Post, I set the record straight by outlining the many ways the law benefits Americans and exactly what we have to lose if it goes away. http://www.denverpost.com/2017/01/27/repealing-the-affordable-care-act-would-endanger-americans-health/

Tonight I joined my Democratic colleagues from the Senate and House on the steps of the U.S. Supreme Court to demand that President Trump end his unconstitutional, discriminatory and dangerous #MuslimBan. Leaders around the world, from presidents to the Pope, have condemned this edict, which has slammed the door to safety for millions and jeopardized U.S. national security by alienating Muslims in the United States and abroad. We won’t stand by while the White House undermines our nation’s values, and we’ll use all legal channels available to resist this irresponsible move.

I’m speaking out to protect our health care system during three Energy and Commerce Committee hearings this week. At today’s meeting of the Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee, on which I’m ranking member, fellow Democrats joined me in defending Medicaid against dishonest attacks and discussed ways to strengthen this crucial program.

#BlackHistoryMonth is a chance to take stock of changes over time to American society. From afar, the centuries-long legacy of African Americans is a dynamic and often tragic patchwork, but a closer look reveals the individual stories of brave men and women who dared to challenge the status quo and fought for acknowledgement, representation and equality. This month should not only be an occasion to honor the accomplishments of black Americans, but also an opportunity to recognize those currently engaged in the ongoing quest for justice.

I will never stand for dishonest attacks on the healthcare reforms that have helped our community and our nation thrive. At yesterday’s Health Subcommittee hearing focused on Medicaid, I told the story of a previously uninsurable Denver resident whose life was drastically improved thanks to this crucial program’s expansion through the ACA. #ProtectOurCare

At today's Energy and Commerce hearing, our third of the week, I once again defended the Affordable Care Act from false and misleading charges against its effectiveness. Republicans have vowed to repeal the #ACA for nearly seven years, but in that time they have failed to create any viable replacement plan. Meanwhile, millions of people have gained coverage through the law. Is it worth it to the GOP to make good on their threats even when it means disaster for our country? I challenge them to examine their consciences, where they will easily find the answer. #ProtectOurCare

Many thanks to the nearly 1000 constituents who came to our community forum in Denver today. We covered a lot of ground, from the President's distressing recent Executive Orders on immigration and refugees to how the debate on the Affordable Care Act is changing thanks to public pressure on Congress. Stay engaged!

As a founding member of the Congressional LGBT Equality Caucus, I’ve been heartened to witness its tremendous growth and am proud to join once more for the 115th Congress. #LGBTQ Americans have gained so much in recent years, but now have even more to lose at the hands of politicians who want to turn back the clock on equality. We won’t let that happen without a fight  -- and our bipartisan caucus, now 102 members strong, will lead the charge.

We must fight to #ProtectOurCare for the children in Colorado and across America whose voices aren’t always heard. Repealing the #ACA and gutting other crucial health programs would devastate children’s care, particularly among the most economically vulnerable. A healthy start boosts potential for lifelong success, and no child should be denied that right.
Thank you, Senator Mitch McConnell, for perfectly encapsulating the power of women in three words: #Nevertheless, she persisted.
Thanks to the Denver Green School for inviting my staff to a climate change summit today led by kids with a passion for the planet. @DenverPublicSchools

#MichaelFlynn’s resignation from his National Security Advisor post comes the day after I signed a letter with 40 other House Democrats calling for his suspension. It appears that our concerns over his ties to Russia, and his failure to disclose them, were well-founded. While it is good that Mr. Flynn is no longer in a position of trust within our government, this development only underscores how little we know about the Trump transition’s ties to Russia and any lingering risks. We need a bipartisan inquiry into this matter.
#ToImmigrantsWithLove: We are with you. Never let intolerance and xenophobia keep you from standing tall, because you're in good company.

#JeanetteBelongsHere. I join the chorus of voices in Colorado and across America showing solidarity with Jeanette Vizguerra and those like her who risk deportation but deserve a chance to stay in this country. President Trump is right that our immigration system is broken, but ripping mothers and fathers away from their children is not the fix we need. Jeanette is a leader in immigrants’ rights; many more like her remain silent for fear of reprisal.

The federal government should take a page from Colorado’s playbook to protect the environment and the economy. At today’s Environment Subcommittee hearing I spoke about Colorado’s Voluntary Cleanup and Redevelopment Program, created by my legislation in the state legislature in 1994. It gave businesses incentives to redevelop brownfield sites that had been sitting vacant for years. Since then, thousands of brownfield sites in our state have been given a new life. Smart protection can yield big rewards.

Today I led the debate in the House of Representatives against H.J. Res. 43, a Republican plan to roll back funding for family planning and other health services through #TitleX. For more than 40 years, this provision has helped provide crucial health services to millions of women who need them most. This resolution is the latest in a long list of GOP attacks on women’s health care options. Today, in a comment on the Affordable Care Act, Speaker Ryan  proclaimed that “Patients and doctors should be making the big decisions. Not government bureaucrats.” If this is true, then why are House Republicans so eager to attack women’s health and ditch #TitleX funds?

If this report is correct, then the President is acting out his most despotic inclinations. Colorado will surely stand against such an action, but how far will this administration try to go to enact its extreme agenda?

On this day in 2009, President Obama signed into law the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act, providing a much-needed economic stimulus, at the Denver Museum of Nature and Science. I was proud to be on hand for that. In the preceding three weeks, he had signed the Lilly Ledbetter Equal Pay Act and an expansion of the State Children’s Health Insurance Program. What a solid month of achievements.

Today marks the 75th anniversary of Executive Order 9066, which authorized the internment of Japanese Americans in camps across the United States, among them Camp Amache in Colorado. Although some people condemned these actions – including the courageous and eloquent then-Colorado Governor Ralph Carr – it was not enough to overcome unsubstantiated fear and unchallenged prejudice. We honor the men and women who lived through this dark chapter and pledge to always speak out against discrimination.

President’s Trump’s decision to rescind federal guidelines used to #ProtectTransKids in schools across America is shameful. Colorado issued similar rules eight years ago and they have proven successful in creating a welcoming learning environment for every student in our state. These federal rules had the potential to do the same nationwide and to see them rejected is disheartening. Still, it won’t stop the steady progress we’ve made in embracing equality for all members of the LGBTQ community, young and old. We won’t turn back because we’ve come too far.

The #GOP had seven years to devise an alternative to the #ACA, but their draft repeal bill looks like it was pieced together in about seven minutes. What we do know is that this shoddy draft takes a page from the same old Republican playbook, rationing health care for millions of Americans to fund tax breaks for the wealthy and big pharma. We need a healthcare system that reduces the price of prescription drugs, holds down premiums, and lessens the burden of out-of-pocket costs like deductibles. The ACA is not a perfect law, but Congress should work together to keep what works in the ACA and fix what doesn’t. Repealing and replacing with bad policies will only take us backwards. I pledge to continue opposing these repeal efforts. #ProtectOurCare.

As ranking member on the Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee, I'm looking forward to delving into the serious issue of doping in sports at a hearing next Tuesday, with decorated Olympian Michael Phelps providing testimony, among others. Doping has become institutionalized, as we saw in 2014 when it was revealed that more than 1,000 athletes on Russia's Olympic team were taking performance enhancing drugs. We have reached a point in international sports where authorities such as the World Anti-Doping Agency may need better tools to ensure a level playing field. This hearing and others like it should help ensure that what happened in the Russian athletics program is never repeated.

The 21st Century Cures Act became law in December, but how do we ensure now - in a changed environment - that it lives up to its promise of revolutionizing biomedical research to save millions of lives? I’ll be discussing this and more with my colleague Fred Upton at a panel discussion tomorrow hosted by The Hill. Be sure to watch live here: http://thehill.com/event/316159-the-value-of-a-cure-ensuring-access-and-encouraging-innovation  #TheValueofaCure

The Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee of which I’m ranking member heard today from Olympic champion @MichaelPhelps and others about maintaining a level playing field by preventing doping. Russia’s widespread doping program, discovered in 2014, has the potential to harm permanently the reputation of international sports and the thousands of athletes who compete with integrity. We owe it to our American athletes to ensure they have a fair chance in competition. When dealing with Russia and its approach to ensuring clean, international competitions, the honor system is simply not going to be enough.

For the past month, President Trump and Republican leaders in Congress have been giving us platitudes and promises, but no real plans on anything from health care to immigration to education and beyond. Meanwhile, the president's actions speak louder than any number of grand pronouncements he made this evening. His draft budget is completely out of line with U.S. values and long-term interests. He talks about things that will be wildly expensive, but then offers no way to pay for them but vague assurances of tax cuts. These things sound great in a speech, but the reality has set in: As president, you have to put in place workable policies.

Last night, I attended President Trump’s address to a joint session of Congress in good faith, hoping to hear a substantive policy vision. What we heard instead was a collection of promises and platitudes, but no real plan to tackle systemic national issues that must be addressed. It appears he will continue to double down on his dangerous policies affecting immigrants and refugees while peddling a proposed budget that evidently prioritizes the very wealthy at the expense of the middle class and inflates military spending while gutting diplomacy. If the president continues to go down this treacherous path, I will continue to oppose this agenda because Coloradans and all Americans deserve better.

Today marks the beginning of #WomensHistoryMonth, an occasion to place special focus on the women who have helped shape our world, often in the face of sexism and misogyny. We have made impressive progress in the march toward gender equality, but our current political battles over reproductive rights, equal pay and a host of other critical issues remind us how precarious these rights are. As we celebrate the power of women this month, let’s ensure that the legacy of our past reinvigorates our struggle for equal rights, because after all, #TheFutureisFemale.

Attorney General Sessions’ contact with the Russian ambassador while an advisor to the Trump campaign once again proves this administration’s causal relationship with transparency and the truth. Given what we now know, the Attorney General should resign immediately or be removed. This continued stream of information regarding campaign, transition, and administration officials communicating with members of the Russian government and failing to disclose it creates an air of uncertainty about the guidance that the President is receiving from his closest advisors. Congress must establish a transparent inquiry into this crisis since the administration evidently is unwilling to do so.

#FlashbackFriday to two of my favorite guys on one of my proudest days. I’ll treasure this picture of Max Schill, the little boy who helped make #21stCenturyCures a reality, with me and President Obama on the day he signed it into law. Thanks, Max, for your thoughtful gift, and #ThanksObama for reminding us what leadership looks like.
Don't be fooled by President Trump's updated #travelban. These tweaks don't make it any less discriminatory. #NoBanNoWall: http://bit.ly/2lTFzom

The President’s revised travel ban on people from Muslim-majority countries is no better than his previous edict. Americans rose up immediately to tell him the first Executive Order on this matter was wrong. Our allies overseas weighed in, as well. Courts stopped him from proceeding. But President Trump wouldn’t listen, and has now tried again to push through this discriminatory, dangerous directive. #NoBanNoWall

Students at Bruce Randolph School in Denver are taking action against this Republican Administration’s discriminatory policies. They’re spearheading an initiative using social media to deliver a message of inclusion and equality. I’m honored to help amplify the voices of so many socially-engaged young Coloradans whose values will shape and improve our future. #NoBanNoWall

The Energy and Commerce Committee will begin marking up House Republicans’ #ACA replacement bill this morning, less than two full days since it was unveiled. However, it doesn’t take much time to realize that this plan will take America backward and reduce care for millions. As a senior member of the committee, I’m prepared to lead the charge against this dangerous piece of legislation. Watch the livestream and let Republicans know that we are united to #ProtectOurCare

In my opening statement at today’s markup of House Republicans’ bill to dismantle the #ACA, I reminded my colleagues on the right that the American Enterprise Institute has just estimated that 10 to 15 million Americans are expected to lose their health care under this dangerous bill. Are they prepared to face their constituents, friends and neighbors who stand to lose so much if their legislation passes?

House Republicans have been all talk and no substance today when pressed to outline the details of their bill to dismantle the #ACA . That’s because this legislation would take away care from many of their own constituents. It’s no wonder they only belatedly requested a necessary review by the Congressional Budget Office that won’t be released until next week. Facts are not their friends.

It’s going to be a late night (or an early morning), but I’m prepared to defend against the #GOP’s reckless repeal of the #ACA for as long as it takes. We’ve come too far to turn back. Millions of Americans are depending on us to #ProtectOurCare.

The marathon markup of the GOP’s #ACA repeal bill has ended. Although the majority has managed to move this measure forward, Democrats succeeded in forcing Republicans to face the facts: Their bill will hurt millions of people in Colorado and across America. I offered amendments blocking the effort to defund Planned Parenthood and constraining insurance companies’ ability to dramatically increase out-of-pocket costs, including deductibles. Both amendments were defeated on party-line votes.  We did all we could for now, but we’re not giving up until this bill is either fixed or scrapped. #ProtectOurCare.

The Congressional Budget Office has confirmed that the #Trumpcare bill will take a terrible toll. It will deprive 14 million people of insurance in its first year alone, and 24 million by 2026.  Premiums will spike by 15 to 20 percent in 2018 and 2019, on top of projected increases under the current law. Deductibles will go up, as well. This bill will raise health costs on the middle class while giving tax breaks to the very wealthy, while pushing working families out of health coverage altogether. Now that the facts are clear, we must fight even harder to #ProtectOurCare.

I just returned to DC from Denver, and am pleased to see a piece by fellow Coloradan Adrian Miller prominently featured in today’s Washington Post.  The executive director of Colorado Council of Churches, Adrian’s the author of a new book in which he highlights some of the many African Americans who fed our nation’s first families, from the Washingtons to the Obamas. “The complicated racial history of the presidential kitchen,” as he puts it, provides food for thought as we continue striving for equality and representation.

President Trump’s #budget proposal shows that his priorities are dangerous. I am especially concerned that the president plans to gut the U.S. Department of State, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the National Institutes of Health (NIH), which play crucial roles both at home and abroad. Everyone supports strong national defense, but this plan beefs up military spending at the cost of ensuring a healthy, safe future for all through peaceful means.

Everyone deserves safe drinking water – but that’s far from guaranteed in this country, as the ongoing crisis in #Flint has shown. We can do better by passing the Safe Drinking Water Amendments Act (H.R. 1068), which I am co-sponsoring. At a hearing today on our nation's water delivery systems, I questioned experts on the subject, who agreed that these changes would ensure that every American can trust what comes out of the tap.

On #SaintPatricksDay, I proudly wear green to honor the millions of Irish Americans who have shaped our country for centuries -- including my great grandmother, Anne Delaney, who was lucky enough to have been born on March 17th. You can’t get much more Irish than that.

One of the many misguided budget cuts proposed by President Trump would eliminate the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. For nearly 50 years, the CPB has helped  fund public radio and television for millions. Today’s news that @sesamestreet will debut a character who is on the autism spectrum underscores @pbs's legacy of promoting innovation, learning and inclusiveness. #ILovePBS

Leave it to House Republicans to make a bad bill even worse. In the latest version of the GOP’s disastrous #ACA repeal, states would be allowed to kick new mothers off Medicaid if they can’t find work within 60 days of giving birth. This provision, tucked into a bill that was made public late at night, would turn back the clock on women across our country by violating family leave protections. American families deserve better than House Republicans’ obvious contempt for low-income Americans.

The Hill goes to every congressional office and is widely read online. In today’s edition, on the eve of a scheduled vote in the House, I warn of the disastrous consequences Americans can expect if Republicans pass #Trumpcare, including loss of health coverage for millions. I urge my colleagues to throw out this bad piece of legislation and instead work across the aisle to improve coverage under the Affordable Care Act. With a little political courage, Congress can accomplish this goal for the American people without hurting millions of them in the process.

As the White House keeps up its last-minute attempt to jam #Trumpcare through the House today, President Obama reminds us of all that the Affordable Care Act has achieved in the seven years since he signed it into law. I remember that day vividly – it was full of excitement and optimism. While the #ACA – like so many other complex laws  -- is not perfect, it has achieved our goal of insuring millions and improving the health and well-being of our entire nation. We should work on bipartisan solutions to fix the system where needed, and not throw it out altogether. Let’s #ProtectOurCare.
How #TrumpCare will damage America.

As the #TrumpCare vote looms, this is my pledge: I will NEVER vote for legislation that rips health coverage from the most vulnerable – the poor, children, seniors and others – and leaves everyone with less care at a higher cost. Those aren’t the values of Colorado or America. We will #ProtectOurCare

#TrumpCare is scheduled for a House vote this afternoon. More and more GOP House members are announcing their opposition to the bill. It’s no wonder: Americans are rejecting TrumpCare in growing numbers.  It will leave just about everyone worse off, with less care at a higher cost. For my constituents and for all Americans, I‘ll keep fighting to #ProtectOurCare.
Thank you for your support in helping to defeat #Trumpcare

After the stunning defeat of #TrumpCare, Congressional Republicans face a crossroads: They can continue to malign and undermine the Affordable Care Act, or they can finally agree to work with Democrats to seek bipartisan fixes to the law. In today’s New York Times, I urge my colleagues to choose the latter. #ACA remains the law of the land, and we must all take ownership of our country’s health care to ensure that it provides affordable, high-quality coverage for all.

To all Colorado students with a passion for public service: There’s an information session on America’s service academies next month. The choice by young people to apply to these prestigious schools speaks volumes about their commitment to our country, to their communities, and to their own personal development. If you’d like to be one of them, this informative event will help provide the tools you need.

President Trump’s executive order undoing many Obama-era climate actions sacrifices the health of every American and our progress in tackling climate change – all so polluters can make a quick buck at our expense. I oppose these actions in the strongest of terms, both as a member of the Subcommittee on the Environment and as a native Coloradan with a lifelong appreciation for our public lands, and I will continue to #defendclimate.

I spoke on the House floor today in defense of online privacy. Congress was considering S.J. Res 34, which removes protections that keep Internet Service Providers from being able to sell Americans’ browsing history to a third party – be it an advocacy group, a for-profit company, or even a foreign government. At its core, this bill weakens consumer protections today and makes them harder to implement in the future, which is why I urged my colleagues to oppose it.

Today I spoke at the National Press Club about reforming health care in the new political era. The GOP bill to repeal and replace the #ACA is gone – at least for now.  The time is now ripe to shift back to constructive, bipartisan discussions of how to improve the existing law. With a combination of political courage, productive engagement and mutual goodwill, Republicans and Democrats can come together even in these hyper-partisan times, just as we did to pass #21stCenturyCures. Watch my remarks below.

I'm very concerned over the Trump administration's decision to not include questions in the U.S. Census to survey #LGBTQ individuals. Answers to these questions help determine federal funding for services that benefit this group. Such actions show that the President wants to pick and choose which Americans count. We all count, including the millions of LGBTQ Americans who contribute to their communities in Colorado and across the country. Representation matters, and I pledge to fight for the acknowledgement of every American.

On this International Transgender Day of Visibility, I join the #TransResistance in support of the worldwide transgender community fighting for acceptance, representation and empowerment. We are with you.

A hundred years ago this Sunday, Jeannette Rankin became the first female member of Congress. During her time in the House and throughout her life, Rankin advocated pacifism, fought for voting rights and supported numerous other causes on moral grounds. She inspired many of us to serve our communities through elected office – not in spite of our gender, but because of it.

Picture it: A society where hard work is equally rewarded, regardless of gender. On #equalpayday and every day, women across America will earn less than their male counterparts for doing the same work. This is unacceptable. I have been heartened by the progress women have made through the years, but it’s clear that true equality won’t be reached until men and women reach economic parity. Achieving this goal will benefit every American family because when women succeed, we all succeed.

I’m proud to be a co-sponsor of the #BRIDGEAct, (H.R. 496). This bipartisan legislation protects #DACA-eligible people from deportation, letting them come out of the shadows and reach for their American dream. Our country must reject incendiary rhetoric and draconian policies concerning undocumented people. We are strengthened by welcoming newcomers. This bill is a great step forward in achieving this important goal.

Today I joined forces with Congressman Jared Polis, Congresswoman Jan Schakowsky and Congressman Matt Cartwright to introduce a package of five bills that will protect public health and the #environment from the risks of oil and gas production, including hydraulic fracking. The Safe Energy Future Plan aims to improve the current patchwork of regulations and loophole-filled laws that have led to irresponsible mineral extraction that endangers nature and the public. For the safety of all our communities, we need to ensure that the oil and gas industries are held accountable, and this legislation helps achieve this goal.

About what’s happening in #Syria: Chemical weapons use on anyone is horrific and calls for a response. However, the context for last night’s action is a wider, brutal conflict. Happy #Passover to all who observe this special holiday -- a reminder that faith and unity can overcome oppression.

In the Colorado Statesman, I outline the ways repealing the #ACA would be disastrous for so many in Colorado, including adults over 50, who would likely see a dramatic spike in premiums. President Trump and congressional Republicans continue to vow a full repeal of this important law, and we must all remain passionate and vigilant in the fight to #ProtectOurCare. I urge my colleagues across the aisle to change course and commit to a bipartisan effort to improve the ACA, ensuring that every American has fair and affordable health coverage.

In Morning Consult, Fred Upton and I make a strong case against the President’s proposed budget cuts to National Institutes of Health (NIH), but I am also just as concerned by the administration’s recent directive to reorganize and potentially cut large swaths of the federal workforce that would include this entity as well as the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. The success of #21stCenturyCures rests heavily on the strength of these two agencies. We need to retain talent and recruit the best and the brightest to ensure that the promise of this sweeping legislation is fulfilled. Dramatic personnel and budget cuts will cost jobs and could sacrifice life-saving cures for millions.

Today I was honored to speak at a naturalization ceremony held at the Denver Public Library. Joined by Mayor Michael B. Hancock, city librarian Michelle Jeske, the West High School JROTC and other civic leaders, we proudly congratulated this brand new group of Coloradans and American citizens on the hard work, diligence and passion they exhibited to achieve this goal. Citizenship is a solemn responsibility, and I commend these men and women for accepting it with pride and a commitment to upholding the US Constitution.
#HappyEaster to everyone in Colorado and around the world observing this celebration of renewal and hope.

#JeanetteVizguerra’s activism, bravery and struggle have put a human face on the millions of undocumented persons and mixed-status families who face the daily threat of deportation. For this, she has been included in TIME's #Time100 list of the world’s most influential people. Congratulations, Jeanette, on this great honor – though the time for true celebration will come when our broken immigration system is finally changed to respect the humanity of every person.

We capped this year’s Congressional Art Competition with a ceremony last night. Thanks so much to my many creative young constituents who took part, and to the families and instructors at regional high schools who have supported and inspired them.  Art plays an important role in the education and development of students. It nourishes the imagination, engages the intellect and teaches persistence. As a member of the Arts Caucus in Congress, promoting the arts is important to me, and this is one of my favorite events of the year.

#EarthDay is a special observance for me as a Coloradan and a member of the Subcommittee on the Environment. But this year, it’s even more crucial since President Trump and his #GOP allies in Congress are working to roll back the progress we’ve made in fighting #climatechange, reducing pollution, and holding oil and gas companies accountable. On top of that, the President has proposed a 31% cut to the @epagov budget. I’ll continue to stand against these attacks and advocate for legislation that protects nature and our communities.  Let’s all do our part to #defendclimate.

As President Trump approaches his 100th day on office, he faces historically low approval ratings and public trust in his leadership. And no wonder: among the reasons are countless broken promises to Americans. On jobs, trade, infrastructure and more, President Trump has said one thing and done another, making our country weaker at home and abroad.

50 years ago today, #Colorado blazed a trail for the rights of women and girls when it became the first state to loosen restrictions on legal abortions. Until then, the procedure was available only if the woman’s life was at stake. In a statement in the Congressional Record today, I honor the bill’s author, Richard Lamm – then a freshman legislator and later Colorado’s governor – State Senator John Bermingham, then-Governor John Love and all others involved for their courage in passing this ground-breaking law and standing against anti-choice extremism.

After their terrible #TrumpCare legislation crashed and burned in March, House Republicans are now back with an even worse version. Their latest #ACA repeal scheme would saddle Americans with higher costs, remove key protections and rip coverage away from even more people. Once again, It’s up to those of us who believe that health care is a human right to  #resist this harmful legislation and work to #protectourcare.

Today I’m honored to participate in @girlsinc's Daughter for a Day event. My special guest is Esperanza Magallanes, a bright high school senior from Oakland, California who will attend UC Berkeley next year and plans to work in public service. I had the pleasure of guiding Esperanza through a busy morning, and even introduced her to her representative, @repbarbaralee Wonderful to meet you, Esperanza, and good luck with your big plans for the future.
For #100days we've endured a dangerous presidency, but we've also been more united in defense of our values than before. Keep #resisting.

Happy #PrideMonth! #LGBTQ rights have come a long way in this country – from the first whispers of equality that became a roar after #stonewall to the successful effort to legalize same-sex marriage. In between have been decades of struggle, activism and tragedy. This month, we honor these pioneers and strive to build upon their legacy. The forces of bigotry and intolerance will not go unchallenged in this or any area of civil rights. I will continue pushing back against rhetoric and policies that seek to harm LGBTQ individuals across our country and around the world.

President Trump’s announcement that he is pulling America out of the #ParisAgreement signals that our country cannot be counted on to stick to its promises and is prepared to cede leadership in yet another area that is crucial to our future. It’s dismaying that he evidently is willing to renege on an accord to which all countries but Syria and Nicaragua have agreed. Why is he looking to alienate the United States?

On #GunViolenceAwarenessDay, we proudly #wearorange to honor the lives lost to senseless #gunviolence, and the countless other lives it has damaged in Colorado and across America. Our state knows the severity of this problem all too well. That’s why I was proud to cosponsor legislation that would officially recognize this day as a national commemoration and designate June as National Gun Violence Awareness Month. America needs common-sense gun violence prevention to end this scourge; creating a national dialogue is an excellent first step to saving lives and making our communities safer.

June is #AlzheimersAwarenessMonth. About 67,000 Coloradans live with this heartbreaking disease, not to mention their loved ones who serve as caregivers, and millions more around the world can expect to suffer from it if current trends continue. That’s why it’s critical to find treatment and cures. #21stCenturyCures, my biomedical research bill that became law in December, will provide more funding and ease regulatory burdens to allow new discoveries. We have much work ahead in the fight against Alzheimer’s, but we’ve also come very far in our understanding of it. I know that with continued research and advocacy, we can #ENDAlz together.

Today’s #ComeyHearing has unearthed disturbing revelations and raised even more questions. By Mr. Comey’s account and those of others, the President of the United States appears to have tried to influence the FBI’s investigation concerning the Trump campaign, Trump White House personnel and Russian efforts to interfere with the 2016 election. What remains unclear is the full extent of the administration’s attempts to sway the FBI inquiry and the extent of Russia’s influence on our country’s politics. Americans are demanding answers to these critical questions, which is why  I reaffirm my support of the special counsel appointed to probe the matter, and renew the call for an independent commission to reach longer-term solutions.

One year ago, a deadly mix of homophobia and easy access to firearms resulted in one of the most horrific mass shootings in American history, leaving 49 victims dead and 58 injured. One year after #Pulse, the voices of bigotry remain – and in some cases, are even stronger now – while Republicans and their allies continue to block comprehensive gun safety legislation. To honor the #PulseVictims and their loved ones, and to protect all our communities, we must keep working passionately to #DisarmHate. For now, we stand with the people of Orlando in grief, solidarity and #pride.

I joined 195 of my Democratic colleagues in filing a lawsuit against President Trump over his accepting profits from foreign entities without congressional approval. Enforcing the Emoluments Clause of the Constitution is an important and necessary step to safeguard our democracy and ensure the President’s actions are for the benefit of our nation, not his wallet.

This morning, Mike DeBonis of the Washington Post engaged me, Congressman Greg Walden and Senator Edward J. Markey in an important discussion on addiction in America, particularly #opioid abuse. While Sen. Markey and I are often at odds with Rep. Walden and his fellow Republicans, the three of us have all heard tragic stories of addiction in our communities and are committed to alleviating it. I stressed that while money is not a panacea, smart federal investments through legislation like #21stCenturyCures, my biomedical research bill that became law last year, present a path forward. In addition, increasing knowledge of addiction and a greater focus on holistic approaches can provide a lifeline for millions in Colorado and across America embroiled in this public health crisis. #PostLive

Insulin is a lifeline for millions, but because of rising costs and inadequate coverage, it’s in danger of becoming a luxury. We can’t let that happen, which is why Rep. Tom Reed and I, Co-Chairs of the Congressional Diabetes Caucus, have sent a letter to three key stakeholders asking them for answers. We need more information from industry to develop bipartisan policy solutions that will make insulin more affordable for all Americans. Patients and their families want relief, and this meeting will provide a necessary first step to ensuring every American with diabetes has the ability to thrive.

The Senate has just revealed a bill, developed in secret, to dismantle the Affordable Care Act. Coloradans have a lot to say about this Republican scheme and the one in the House before that. I’ve heard poignant and heartfelt stories from many constituents on what coverage under the #ACA means for you and your families. On the 45th anniversary of #TitleIX, I’m especially thankful for the expansion of educational and extracurricular opportunities that have helped create successive generations of bold women who are undaunted by past limitations. While we have yet to achieve true gender equality, we can look to this groundbreaking law for inspiration and guidance as we move forward. There is no limit to what women and girls can achieve, and Title IX has revealed that truth to millions.

The non-partisan Congressional Budget Office has just issued an assessment of the Senate bill to dismantle the Affordable Care Act (ACA).This latest version of #Trumpcare is even worse than previous ones. It will harm many people and lead to needless deaths. It will rip coverage away from 22 million people and raise costs for many millions of others. Meanwhile, the same heartless measure gives tax breaks to the ultra-wealthy. If you have views on the bill, or stories you’d like to share about how the #ACA has helped you, write them in the comments of the post at the top of this page. Make your voice heard in the Senate.

My Energy and Commerce Committee colleagues and I considered several important bills today. Of particular interest: the Promoting Conduit Hydropower Facilities (H.R. 2786) Act, my bill with North Carolina Republican Rich Hudson that promotes new energy projects using existing infrastructure. Hydropower is a clean, domestic energy source that has provided almost six percent of U.S. electricity and almost half of this country’s renewable electricity in the past two years through projects big and small. Our bill will advance hydropower in a way that respects existing water rights and minimizes environmental disruption. I’m happy to say the committee approved it unanimously amid a spirit of bipartisan cooperation – something I’d like to see more of in Congress as a whole.

Today I objected strongly to H.R. 1215, a regressive #GOP bill that restricts patients’ rights to seek justice through the courts. Someone named it the Protecting Access to Care Act, but that’s completely misleading. Read my statement below outlining why this legislation would literally add insult to injury.

I was inspired by the strength and passion of so many who gathered at the rally to #SaveOurCare at the U.S. Capitol. Groups representing women’s health, organized labor and more came together united in the goal of stopping #Trumpcare. I carried the photo of a constituent – one of many – who shared with me why the #ACA has been a lifeline for her and her family. I fight for these Coloradans, and every American, who depend on coverage through this groundbreaking law. We’ve made progress in the fight to #ProtectOurCare but the battle is far from over.

Democratic colleagues and I gathered, wearing somber expressions, dark clothes and veils, to #MournMedicaid. This 52-year-old program is under threat by the ongoing #GOP assault – both through the President’s proposed budget and the #Trumpcare bill they’re trying to pass. These efforts will strip care from millions of the most vulnerable people in our society, including children in low-income families and many older Americans. If the Republican leadership truly cares about our country’s health, they should work with Democrats to strengthen it.

I’m proud to be an original co-sponsor of the bipartisan H.R. 3044, which lets Medicare Advantage insurance plans offer a wider variety of benefits to the chronically ill. By letting plans cover supplemental benefits that are not traditionally covered by Medicare Advantage, such as case management and meal delivery, we can improve health outcomes and quality of life for seniors who have complex care needs. As America’s senior population continues to increase, there’s an ever greater need for smart solutions to improve every American’s later years; this bill is an important step in that direction.

I also asked that you share your views of the Senate bill. I’ve been inspired by your many passionate and heartfelt notes outlining why coverage through the ACA for you, your families and your loved ones is so important. In this video, I’m reading notes from Sarah Orsborne and Kelly Benson, who implore Republicans to end their unilateral efforts to repeal this lifeline for millions. Share your stories in the comments below, and be sure to include your Zip code at the end. I intend to hand-deliver them personally to our Colorado Senators. #ProtectOurCare

Wishing you and your loved ones a fun-filled and meaningful Fourth of July. While America grapples with a startling crisis of leadership, I’m thankful to see people rise to the occasion by insisting on enduring American ideals – freedom of expression, compassion, inclusion, peaceful protest and more. Our nation is an ever-changing work in progress, but it remains a beacon of hope and liberty around the world. Today, and every day, we must unite to protect and strengthen the values that define us.

I’m sharing a double #TBT today – first to a recent chance meeting with a former classmate in Denver who took me back even further by sharing his copy of our high school yearbook. If you look closely, you’ll see a familiar-looking Denver South High School student with 70’s hair and dreams of making a difference in the world. Moments like this, along with my visit to South High earlier this year,  reaffirm my pride in the special community where I’ve spent my life.

I can’t think of a more fitting and meaningful way to observe the week of the Fourth than by honoring those who have chosen to make America their home. Today I was proud to welcome a diverse group of 80 brand-new citizens at a naturalization ceremony held at Denver City Hall. The men and women I met hail from all corners of the globe and came to America for different reasons, but they are united by a shared passion and loyalty for their adopted homeland. Our nation is made stronger by immigrants, and we must ensure the U.S. remains a beacon of opportunity, refuge and acceptance.

Two years ago, the House of Representatives passed #21stCenturyCures, creating a model of bipartisan cooperation that brought the promise of speedier research and life-saving cures for millions of people around the globe. I was proud to co-author this bill with Republican Congressman Fred Upton of Michigan; together, we shepherded it through to become law last December. Today, as the White House and Republicans continue their efforts to repeal the #ACA unilaterally, I urge them to take a page from the Cures playbook and work together with Democrats for everyone’s benefit. Achieving bipartisan improvements to the law is the only way to ensure that millions of Americans don’t lose health coverage now – and millions more can depend on coverage through the ACA in the future. #ProtectOurCare

Today in Denver, I spoke on the dangers of #Trumpcare and heard from two Coloradans engaged in the fight to #ProtectOurCare. Kelly Baker was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis as a teenager and found her career path limited due to her preexisting condition, but through coverage under the #ACA she has been able to follow her dream of becoming an environmental scientist. Ashley Edelman is a woman’s health practitioner who has referred many of her lower-income patients to Planned Parenthood for life-saving screenings and procedures. She worries that Trumpcare’s gutting of this critical resource will irreparably harm many of the women she treats. Every member of Congress represents people like Kelly and Ashley who depend on the ACA for many different reasons. I implore my Republican colleagues in the House and Senate, which is now considering its version of Trumpcare, to take these stories to heart rather than voting to rip away care from millions of people. Tell your stories on my Facebook page. I intend to deliver them to our Colorado Senators.

The facts show that passage of the Affordable Care Act in 2010 was much more transparent than the #Trumpcare process thus far. In the 111th Congress, Democrats conducted multiple hearings, held thorough markups, and took extensive testimony from many witnesses to ensure all stakeholders played a role in the law’s creation.  In contrast, the current #GOP-controlled effort to dismantle the #ACA has largely occurred behind closed doors with little input from Democrats or the public.  Republicans must reject these efforts and join Democrats to improve the ACA in a transparent process. This is the only way to protect and improve care for all Americans.

President Trump’s FCC has proposed a roll-back of critical #netneutrality protections that are key to a free and open internet. Today, I’m joining millions of Americans in rejecting this agenda. Net neutrality ensures free speech online and helps small businesses thrive in the digital economy, creating good jobs in Colorado and across America. What’s more, gutting these protections could give corporations the power to control what you can and can’t access online, potentially stifling the kind of online grassroots organizing that spurred movements such as Black Lives Matter and the Women’s March. The FCC should maintain the rules for the free and open internet, not dismantle them. Take action and make your voice heard.

I’m proud to be part of a bipartisan group of House and Senate colleagues who’ve just introduced legislation that will help get #everykidoutdoors through expanded access to our national parks. The Every Kid Outdoors Act codifies into law the recent successful effort by the U.S. Interior Department to offer fourth graders and their families free entrance to all federally-managed public lands, resulting in record-setting visits to national parks last year. The outdoors is central to Colorado's way of life and our economy. Today’s fourth graders are tomorrow’s outdoor entrepreneurs and conservationists. Getting these students outside to enjoy our public lands – such as Rocky Mountain National Park or Black Canyon of the Gunnison – will help inspire future leaders to protect these wild places.

At a time of hyper-partisanship, I was pleased to speak on the House floor today in favor of a bipartisan bill reauthorizing user fees for the Food and Drug Administration. The FDA must continue promoting medical innovation and supporting public health. To do so, it needs consistent funding, which this bill helps assure. It also helps ensure that #21stCenturyCures, the biomedical innovation bill I co-authored with Fred Upton of Michigan, lives up to its promise by helping the FDA establish a process to qualify so-called “biomarkers.” This will facilitate the development of future cutting-edge therapies that can improve treatment and save lives.

On the day the Senate version of #Trumpcare was revealed last month, I asked you to share your views of that bill, as well as stories on why the #ACA is important to you and your families. The comments have come flowing in on social media, in emails and in conversations with you while I've been at home. Your many notes have been poignant, informative and passionate, and I thank you for making your voices heard. We've collected your views and delivered them to our Colorado senators, Senator Michael Bennet and Senator Cory Gardner, who need to hear them as well before they  vote on the next version of the bill. #Trumpcare would be a disaster for our country, and your stories prove it.

Unilateral Senate tweaks to #Trumpcare aren’t the solution. The non-partisan Congressional Budget Office showed last month that the Senate Republicans’ bill would rip coverage away from 22 million people. We’ll now await the CBO’s verdict on the latest iteration of Trumpcare, but no amount of repair to this deeply flawed bill will lead to a product that truly addresses ongoing issues in our health care system. Polls show most Americans think the parties should work together to mend the Affordable Care Act, not end it. That means abandoning Trumpcare and working on bipartisan solutions to the problems the American people want us to solve. In my latest post on Medium, I outline the steps that must be taken to achieve bipartisan health care reform that benefits people over party.

The Senate GOP‘s latest  #Trumpcare bill is even more cruel than the version they abandoned last month. The tweaks made to the bill won’t address the damage it would do to millions of Americans who would lose health care or be forced to pay more for it. Still included are substantial and heartless cuts to Medicaid, significantly higher costs for working families and seniors, and provisions that gut protections for those with pre-existing conditions. Republicans should work with Democrats on strengthening America’s health care system. Watch this video and let me know your views.

Ninety-one Americans die each day due to #opioid addiction according to the Centers for Disease Control; some people are using this epidemic to line their pockets. Patient brokers, or body brokers, target opioid users by helping them book stays at luxurious treatment centers, for which the brokers get kickbacks, and they’ll often sign patients up for flimsy insurance plans to cover the cost. Once the coverage runs out, the patient is kicked out of treatment and the broker moves on to his or her next victim. This is an unconscionable practice, which is why leading members of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce are asking U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price for information on the steps being taken to fight these schemes – and we’re urging stronger oversight to prevent them. Body brokers must not be able to profit from the suffering of others, and shady treatment centers that employ them to fill beds must be shut down. Millions of Americans struggle with opioid addiction; we must work to ensure their efforts to achieve sobriety end in success, not swindling and tragedy.

Most of my #GOP congressional colleagues who are heading to their home states and districts for the weekend will once again have to defend another terrible iteration of #Trumpcare. The Senate bill released yesterday is even more cruel than the previous version. It includes substantial cuts to Medicaid, higher costs to working families and seniors, and fewer protections for people with pre-existing conditions. Next week’s report on the bill by the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office will likely show many millions of people still losing coverage, despite cosmetic tweaks to the bill. It’s time Republicans listen to their constituents; polls say the majority of whom want Congress to work together to repair the #ACA, not repeal it. I’ve been urging this plan of action; my post on Medium this week outlines the steps we must take to achieve lasting bipartisan reforms.

Democrats held 36 hearings on the Affordable Care Act before it became law and expanded coverage for millions of people. The #GOP has held only five on their #Trumpcare legislation that aims to dismantle the #ACA, ripping coverage away from millions and making it far more costly for millions of others. With so much at stake, why are they leaving Americans in the dark? Since the Senate is adjusting its timeline for action on Trumpcare, there's more time to examine this proposal closely and see if it really addresses the country's health care needs. To achieve this goal, I’m calling for House and Senate hearings to reveal the truth about what the Senate’s bill would mean for every American.

I joined more than 70 members of Congress in urging President Trump’s purported voter fraud commission to withdraw its request for voter registration data. This effort to collect Americans’ personal information is based on the false and unsubstantiated claim that millions of people voted illegally in the 2016 election. The commission’s work as proposed is nothing more than a sham investigation that puts voters’ personal information in danger of identity theft. What’s more, the commission has already created a dangerous chilling effect – reports show that more than 3,000 people in Colorado canceled their voter registrations after the request for information. Maintaining the integrity of our elections is a critical priority, but this effort is just a ruse. I commend the 40 states that have rejected this witch-hunt and will continue working to protect voters’ privacy.

Today the House overwhelmingly approved the Small Promoting Conduit Hydropower Facilities Act of 2017 (H.R. 2786), my bipartisan bill with Rep. Rich Hudson of North Carolina that promotes new energy projects using existing infrastructure. Hydropower is a clean, domestic energy source that has provided almost six percent of U.S. electricity and almost half of all renewable electricity. It also supports hundreds of thousands of good jobs across the country. As a westerner, I know how important water is to our environment and our communities, and as a senior member of the Energy and Commerce committee, I’m proud that this bill’s strong support from Chairman Greg Walden and Ranking Member Frank Pallone has proven what we can achieve when we put partisanship aside and work together to address our country’s energy needs. I urge the Senate to make the same smart choice and put America on the road to a clean energy future by supporting this legislation.

At a hearing of the Oversight and Investigation Subcommittee of which I’m Ranking Member, I spoke about the need for stronger oversight of and support for the 340B Drug Discount Program. Congress created this program 25 years ago to help safety net providers leverage their scarce resources to serve more people, especially low-income and vulnerable patients. Troubling reports from Government Accountability Office and the HHS Office of Inspector General have found there is a need for more oversight to ensure that the program achieves its critical mission. However, I am even more concerned by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid’s recently proposed rule dramatically reducing Medicare Part B drug reimbursements for 340B hospitals. I want to work with this committee to fairly address the 340B program’s problems, but using hearings to attack it won’t solve the crisis of rising prescription drug costs. To achieve this goal, Congress must hold more hearings and consider legislation that will tackle the issue head-on – and we must strengthen resources such as 340B, not gut them

Honored to meet members of the Afghan Girls' Robotics Team who've just won a silver medal at the International Robotics Contest here in DC. Our country must keep it doors open to inspiring people such as these bright young women, not close them. http://bit.ly/2uB3G2E

Today I led my Congressional Pro Choice Caucus colleagues in condemning the anti-choice, anti-woman provisions attacking women’s health and reproductive rights that were included in Fiscal Year 2018 appropriations bills. The House appropriations package is riddled with a shocking number of awful riders that go far beyond anything seen in previous proposals. But this is only one line of attack. Virtually every week, women across the country are waking up to news that their rights and access to care are being stripped away by politicians at the state and federal levels. Between the unprecedented defunding of Planned Parenthood in the President’s proposed budget, expanding the global gag rule, blocking access to low-cost birth control, and much more, the onslaught has been relentless. This has to stop. We will not tolerate any more anti-woman policies in government funding bills. The women of America are fed up, and we are standing by them to defend their rights. As co-chair of the Pro Choice Caucus, I’m prepared to lead that fight because women (and men) are worth it.

For more than six months, Republicans have had complete control in Washington. What do they have to show for it? A health plan that rips coverage away from millions, tax breaks for millionaires and a shocking lack of transparency and accountability. Democrats have #abetterdeal for Americans – a plan to create millions of jobs, crack down on unchecked corporate power and dramatically lower the cost of prescription drugs. It won’t be easy, but we have never shied from finding bold solutions to big problems. The American people deserve better than what we’ve seen so far this year. With a Democratic Congress starting in 2019, a better deal is possible.

Last night, the House unanimously passed The Harry W. Colmery Veterans Educational Assistance Act (#HR3218), which I was proud to co-sponsor. This measure is the most substantial update to the GI Bill since passage of the Post-9/11 GI Bill in 2008. It includes strong education improvements and protections that veterans and military service organizations had proposed. These changes will help new service members, reservists, National Guard members, veterans and survivors/dependents receive the quality education they deserve. We must continue to make good on the promise we made to our veterans with initial passage of the GI Bill more than 70 years ago: Answering the call of duty should be rewarded with opportunity and the chance to succeed, both on and off the battlefield.

After the Senate's long night of debate that culminated in a failed Affordable Care Act repeal vote, Team DeGette showed our thanks to Team Senator Michael Bennet with a big bag of fresh bagels -- hand delivered! You'll need sustenance to keep up the fight to #ProtectOurCare. #ACA #Trumpcare

President Trump’s bigoted decision to reverse an Obama-era policy allowing #transgender people to serve openly in the U.S. military won’t make us any safer. Those serving in and out of uniform on behalf of the United States now will have to leave or keep secrets that put them at risk. This edict forces America backward, well before the questionable days of “Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell,” to the unjust era when service members stayed in the closet to avoid being persecuted or purged. As a founding member of the Congressional LGBT Equality Caucus, I will work to reverse this ill-conceived decision based in the biased notion that America must protect itself from those who seek to protect us.

With its overnight defeat in the Senate, the Republican effort to dismantle the Affordable Care Act has reached a road block. However, the path toward improving the #ACA is not at an end. Bipartisan solutions must be found. I continue to reach out to my colleagues across the aisle to work on those improvements. Maybe now they're ready to do so; Americans certainly are, and they've shown it with their vocal outcry against every version of #Trumpcare this year. Your tireless advocacy was instrumental in this heartening development. For months, I have listened to constituents’ stories on how the #ACA is a lifeline for you and your families, and was able to pass them along as promised to your Colorado senators. When Republicans and Democrats finally come together to make these needed improvements, I will make sure your ideas and concerns aren’t ignored, but instead contribute to making affordable coverage a reality for millions more.

As #DACA’s future hangs in the balance, it’s more important than ever to protect this program and expand its original promise.That’s why I’m honored to cosponsor the #AmericanHopeAct of 2017. This bill allows DACA beneficiaries as well as other immigrant youth to apply for conditional permanent resident status, providing a pathway to citizenship. The bill will also improve college affordability for undocumented youth and other immigrants by repealing rules that limit their access to in-state tuition and college loans. Millions of undocumented residents brought here as children are contributing to our country—some as students, but others as parents, caregivers, full-time workers or military personnel. They are all valued and they all deserve their shot at the American dream.

Yesterday was a wonderful day for families and patients across America. #Trumpcare’s defeat in the Senate was due in no small part to the tireless advocacy of millions of citizens, and we should all be proud of this achievement. But we can’t stop there. All of us in Congress must now come together to work to improve the #ACA in a bipartisan manner. My list of 10 ways to improve health care are provided in the comments below, but please continue sharing your ideas as well – I want to hear them.

Happy #ColoradoDay! Here’s to 141 years of statehood and many more. This special anniversary affirms my passion for the place where I’ve spent my life, raised a family and advocated for my friends and neighbors as a member of the state legislature and then the U.S. Congress. I’m happy to be home to celebrate this occasion and to work with fellow Coloradans on ways to make the future even brighter for the Centennial State.

I had a wonderful time visiting with canvassers for Environment Colorado. We discussed my efforts in Congress to combat the Trump administration’s anti-environment policies and learned about the success of their impressive grassroots activism. These hard-working participants have spoken to more than 60,000 Coloradans about clean energy and sustainability this summer alone. Thanks for your important work across our state and for your wonderful gift – a collage of the group’s many creative signs displayed at rallies. Together we’ll work for a more sustainable Colorado and world.

Today I spoke at Jefferson County’s second annual Aerospace and Defense Small Business Day on the critical need to strengthen and support these industries here in Colorado. Large entities such as Lockheed Martin and small businesses alike have contributed to this critical nexus of 21st century careers, making our state the nation’s number one private-sector aerospace employer. For my part, I will continue working with the entire Colorado delegation to secure funding to keep the shared priorities of the U.S. government and the commercial space industry on track, and will also keep pushing for new, qualified nominees to head NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). Thanks to the innovators represented at this gathering, the future of Colorado is looking very bright.

Last night's celebration of the 150th anniversary of the Denver Press Club was both memorable and meaningful. Together with Denver Mayor Michael B. Hancock, other local dignitaries, renowned Colorado historians, club presidents past and present and many club members, I celebrated the place's colorful history and the critical role that media play today in our democracy. I also helped install a plaque to commemorate the building's entry onto the National Register of Historic Places. What began 150 years ago as a means for frontier-town rival reporters to play poker and debate the news of the day has grown alongside the Front Range to become a magnet for exemplary journalists and a stalwart of our First Amendment rights.

Happy Birthday, President Obama! I’m thankful to have had you as a supporter and partner in my efforts to tackle many important priorities. Whether ending the ban on stem cell research, updating the Toxic Substances Control Act, shepherding the landmark 21st Century Cures Act into law, promoting clean energy, preserving #reprorights and more, you have helped improve the lives of Coloradans and every American. Thank you for showing us what real, principled leadership looks like.

I had a fascinating time visiting Phunkshun Wear in Denver, a small business that combines entrepreneurship and environmentalism. Founded in 2011, the company makes ski masks and other active wear from recycled materials, such as water bottles, and boasts a 99% waste-free production process that’s completely powered by wind energy. Thanks to the team at Phunksun for a great tour and for exemplifying Colorado ingenuity. Small businesses often need a boost to get off the ground, which is why I will continue supporting microloan programs and the intermediary lending pilot program within the Small Business Administration to ensure that Coloradans are able to turn good ideas into great investments for our communities.

On this day in 2009, my friend, Justice Sonia Sotomayor, was sworn in as the first Latina to serve on the Supreme Court. Her historic rise to the highest court in the land is an inspiration for our ongoing work to break barriers and shatter glass ceilings for all.

#ICYMI: Check out Colorado Public Radio’s compelling interview with Kevin Patterson, the CEO of Connect for Health Colorado. While Republican efforts to repeal the #ACA have created uncertainty, our exchange is strong thanks to careful planning and the overall good health of Coloradans. He warns, however, that further sabotage, such as the Trump administration’s threats to eliminate the federal government’s cost-sharing reductions, could significantly reduce residents’ ability to afford insurance. Democrats and Republicans must come together to improve the law and make affordable coverage a reality for millions more. Health care experts and everyday citizens alike know these bipartisan reforms are critical and I’m ready to get to work.

After Saturday’s tragic events in #Charlottesville, which left three people dead and dozens injured, I was heartened to see nearly a thousand Coloradans gather in Denver to protest these heinous actions. Make no mistake—the men and women responsible for the violence in Virginia are motivated by racism and white supremacy, a persistent scourge on our nation. Left unchecked, it can become deadly, as we saw this weekend. Fortunately, love is a much stronger force than hate, and I’m proud of everyone who has condemned these actions and affirmed the simple yet bold truth that all men are created equal.
