Conservation experts and constituents gathered Monday evening for an encouraging discussion about action on climate change. We talked about how to move forward with the goals of the Paris Climate Accord despite actions taken by the Trump administration and the inaction of some of my colleagues in Congress. The forward-looking spirit that we showed in Paris in 2015 is still strong across this country; on the state and local levels, the leadership is stepping up to the challenge of keeping America’s commitments.

Today I met with state and local experts on opioid abuse prevention and treatment to discuss the importance of federal funding for these efforts in Colorado; afterward, we held a news conference to highlight this important health policy issue. Abuse of prescription drugs and the use of heroin are claiming thousands of lives and wrecking even more.  According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, every 19 minutes, an American dies from an unintentional drug overdose – and each day, 78 Americans die from opioid-related overdose. President Donald J. Trump recently declared the situation a national emergency, but without implementation guidelines, it’s unclear what this might mean. As a senior member of the Energy and Commerce Committee, I’ve worked to reduce the epidemic’s impact through legislation that removes federal barriers to implementation of prevention and treatment programs.  And my bipartisan 21st Century Cures Act, which became law in December 2016, included $1 billion over two years to fight opioid abuse.  This funding is awarded to states through grants based on need.  Colorado is receiving $7.8 for opioid treatment and prevention as a result of 21st Century Cures.  The state is using these funds to pay for medication-assisted therapy, family therapy, overdose reversal medications, emergency room pilot studies, training for primary care doctors and nurses, residential treatment and partnerships with law enforcement.

Colorado's #opioid epidemic has become so severe that Denver librarians have told me they want to be better prepared to revive people who overdose on site. People need to be better equipped to respond to this public health crisis, which is why I visited the Harm Reduction Action Center in Denver. There, I received training on how to identify an overdose and administer naloxone, a drug that blocks its effects. Thanks to Executive Director Lisa Raville and Programs Director Kat Humphries for teaching me this valuable skill and for your ongoing efforts to save lives. We must continue working to prevent and treat every stage of opioid addiction. The $7.8 million in federal funding I helped secure for this purpose will go far in achieving this goal.

Happy birthday, National Park Service! To celebrate, all national parks offer free admission today. The wild, pristine lands under the care of this federal agency and others have enriched the lives  of Americans and visitors from around the globe for generations. That’s why I’m pushing back hard on the Trump administration’s proposed shrinking of many #nationalmonuments. I’m also cosponsoring the Every Kid Outdoors Act (H.R. 3186), a bipartisan bill that gives fourth graders and their families free entrance to all federally-managed lands, including national parks. As a life-long Coloradan, I’m committed to honoring and strengthening what has been called America’s best idea.

At last night’s Mi Familia Vota town hall on Noticias Univision Colorado, Congressman Ed Perlmutter and I discussed critical issues for Colorado’s Latino community. We took questions from the anchors, many of which they were relaying from audience members in the room and online. The clip below concerns my firm opposition to any bill that funds President Trump’s ill-conceived border wall. Not only is this policy rooted in discrimination and xenophobia, it’s also a tremendous waste of taxpayer money. Thanks to Univision Colorado for holding this important dialogue. I look forward to more.

I enjoyed my tour of Metropolitan State University of Denver's manufacturing facility in their new Aerospace and Engineering Sciences (AES) building. As Colorado continues to attract high-tech jobs, it's important that our higher education system provides students the education and training to fill them, a priority I've worked to advance in Congress. This state-of-the-art facility integrates industrial design, aerospace science, aviation technology, mechanical and electrical engineering technology, computer science and more, preparing its students for the 21st century economy. Thanks to the MSU faculty and students for the warm welcome and for showing me the bright future of Colorado ingenuity.

54 years ago today, the #MarchOnWashington ignited our nation’s moral conscience. There, Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his “I Have a Dream” speech, a vision of equality and opportunity for all. While much of this dream has been realized, the events of the past several weeks prove we must continue working to eradicate hatred and discrimination. Let’s join together to achieve this goal, united by love, compassion and moral clarity.

Craft beer is big business in Colorado, and I was happy to join the Colorado Brewers Guild to discuss ways to strengthen this growing industry. Thanks to Strange Craft Beer Company for hosting the roundtable and for providing a tour. I'll continue working to support policies that benefit brewers, such as the Craft Beverage Modernization and Tax Reform Act (H.R.747), a bill I cosponsored that lowers brewers' tax burdens. Cheers to promoting our local small businesses!

Where in the world is Scott Pruitt? Last month, fellow ranking Democrats on the Energy and Commerce committee and I sent a letter to EPA’s inspector general requesting a review of Administrator Pruitt’s reportedly high travel expenses. The independent IG has responded and plans to investigate whether these frequent travels, including many to Pruitt’s home state, violate agency policies. At a time when the Trump administration is threatening to slash the EPA’s budget by nearly a third, it is critical that the agency step up its efforts to reduce waste, fraud and abuse.  We need to ensure that any travel by Administrator Pruitt directly serves the agency’s mission.

Thanks to Dr. Huntington Potter and his team of doctors and researchers for the tour of the Rocky Mountain Alzheimer’s Disease Center, a part of University of Colorado Medical School. Alzheimer's remains a confounding and devastating illness, but intensive research like the work done here is helping clarify how to prevent, treat and eventually find a cure for it. This is one reason why I worked to provide an additional $.4.8 billion in funding for the National Institutes of Health in the 21st Century Cures Act, my biomedical research bill that became law last December. #Cures are within reach, and we can #EndALZ, but only if we invest in the people working tirelessly to achieve that goal.

Nearly 17,000 #DREAMers in Colorado alone stand to lose everything if President Trump ends the #DACA program, a decision that could come any day now. DACA recipients are vital members of our community. We must all do our part to ensure these young men and women avoid deportation and have access to a path to citizenship. We can achieve this by passing legislation like the #BRIDGEAct and the American Hope Act. In the coming days, we’ll continue fighting to #DefendDACA because its beneficiaries represent the best of the American dream.

Speaker Ryan has said President Trump should not end #DACA, knowing full well the devastating effects this decision would have on nearly 800,000 young men and women, including more than 17,000 in Colorado. I’m pleased he is now echoing the same calls to action my Democratic colleagues and I have been sounding for some time now. He has been sitting on legislation that would help DACA recipients remain productive members of our community and seek a pathway to citizenship. Now that it looks likely that President Trump will soon end the program, Mr. Ryan is finally moved to act. Well, Mr. Speaker, what are we waiting for? Let’s put legislation on the House floor next week. I’m ready to vote on legislation such as the BRIDGE Act and the American Hope Act that can achieve this. While President Trump may be ready to break the promise we made to #DREAMers , those of us who still believe in DACA’s goals will continue our efforts to fulfill them.

This #LaborDay, let’s honor those who made this holiday possible, particularly the women whose contributions to the labor movement deserve more recognition. The 1911 Triangle Shirtwaist Factory Fire remains one of the worst industrial disasters in America’s history, and most of its 146 victims were women. In its aftermath, protests, such as the one pictured, helped inspire efforts to guarantee better working conditions for every American. We thank them and continue their fight for safe, fair and equitable work.

The announcement that President Trump is ending #DACA is a crushing blow to the 800,000 #DREAMers nationwide, including more than 17,000 in Colorado. When President Obama established the program in 2012, he made a promise to DREAMers that America would help provide a pathway to citizenship that allows them to remain vital members of our communities. Though DACA may not be the means used to achieve this objective, its spirit remains stronger than ever. I am urging House Speaker Paul Ryan to put legislation on the House floor that gives these young men and women the chance to achieve their American dream, such as the bipartisan Dream Act. Let’s work together to do the right thing and keep our promise. DACA is far from done.

President Trump’s decision to end #DACA affects the lives of 800,000 #DREAMers and their families. They face new limitations, but also still have rights. What has not changed is my unwavering support for these young men and women. I stand in solidarity with them, and will continue my efforts to #ProtectDreamers.

I am proud to be a cosponsor of the #DreamAct (H.R. 3440) , a bipartisan bill that will #ProtectDREAMers by letting them stay in the United States. I urge House Speaker Paul Ryan to bring it to a vote without delay. Through #DACA, these young men and women were given assurances for the past five years that they would not be subject to deportation and could place faith in the U.S. government. We cannot break faith with them now. Speaker Ryan should not block the potential pathway to citizenship that this legislation before him affords. Let’s work together to do what's right by these young people and our country.

I’m honored to join the Colorado Ovarian Cancer Alliance in its efforts to fight ovarian cancer. There is no screening test for this type of cancer, so it’s important for women to know the symptoms. If you experience frequent bloating, abdominal pain or pressure, urinary urgency or frequency, or feel full quickly when eating, don’t hesitate to go to your doctor. Listen to your gut feelings -- ovarian cancer has a 93% survival rate when it is detected early -- and #WearTeal to raise awareness and save lives.

The #EquifaxBreach shows how urgent the need is to find better ways to protect personal data. I have made this a priority for several years now, pushing for hearings on the matter in the Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee where I am ranking member and joining fellow Democrats in sending a letter last week to the Government Accountability Office asking the agency to help determine the most effective post-breach services for protecting consumer data. Clearly, as a country we need to craft new means to keep thieves and hackers from obtaining and using personal information. Simply compensating consumers whose data has been hacked with a year of monitoring is not going to be enough. I’ll continue working to ensure that our private data is secure.

Much has changed in the 16 years since the #September11 attacks, but the memories of that day and of the innocent victims remain extremely powerful. In their honor, we must continue to reaffirm and strengthen our commitment to the enduring American values of freedom, unity and diversity. In today’s trying times when these values are tested, this anniversary reminds us of how critical it is to preserve them.

Each year, I’m honored to nominate a select group of young Coloradans for admission to America’s service academies, elite institutions of higher learning that combine educational excellence with military officer training. Students aged 17 to 22 who live in Colorado’s first congressional district, are U.S. citizens and have a passion for public service are encouraged to apply by October 6. The application and further details can be found on my website (see link in the first comment below).

Today we remember #EdithWindsor, who passed away at age 88. After years of activism, she helped secure #marriageequality in the Supreme Court case United States v. Windsor. Her inspiring commitment to civil rights will live on in our continued efforts to uplift #LGBTQ people across America and around the world. #ShePersisted

In 2006, several toddlers in this country died after being given common cough medicines that weren’t properly labeled to alert parents to their risks. The Food and Drug Administration still hasn’t been able to update safety requirements for those products due to an outmoded review system. More than 300,000 medicines are regulated through a review process that hasn’t been updated in 40 years despite scientific advancements and growth in the market. Today the Health Subcommittee discussed my bipartisan Over-the-Counter Monograph Safety, Innovation and Reform Act. This bill gives the FDA new tools to protect consumers and would provide the agency with badly-needed resources to safely streamline reviews, potentially saving lives.

Today I spoke on the House floor against the anti-choice #PalmerAmendment, a tack-on to the #GOP spending bill that would overturn Washington DC’s Health Non-Discrimination Act (RHNDA). This would let employers discriminate against women based on their reproductive health choices. A woman should never have to worry that she could be punished—or even fired—for a personal choice about her body, such as using birth control or having an abortion. I urged my colleagues to vote down this violation of women’s and state’s rights. As co-chair of the Pro Choice Caucus, I will continue working to ensure every woman can make her health care decisions.

Today is the beginning of #HispanicHeritageMonth, a celebration of the enormous contributions of Hispanic and Latino Americans across Colorado and our entire country. Through the arts,  politics, activism, science, journalism and more, this diverse group now numbering more than 57 million has made an indelible mark. This year, affirming their value in our country is more important than ever as many face new challenges, such as the hundreds of thousands of DREAMers who could face deportation after the rescinding of #DACA if Congress doesn’t offer a legislative solution. As the representative of a large, growing and dynamic Hispanic community, I will continue working to uplift  and empower this group whose roots lie in Latin America but whose hearts are firmly in this country. #ProtectDREAMers

On a sunny day in Denver, I spoke on the growing storm clouds in Washington surrounding the renewal of the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP). Funding for this critical program that covers about 90,000 children and pregnant women in our state is set to expire at the end of this month. At the Federico F. Peña Southwest Family Health Center, Dr. Steve Federico, Director of General Pediatrics, and Andrew C. Montoya, a parent with a child enrolled in CHIP, joined me in urging Congress to reject partisan wrangling and renew the program. A revived debate over #ACA repeal through the latest #GrahamCassidy legislation is distracting us from meeting this important deadline that will protect millions of kids. Republicans owe it to them to move past their dangerous repeal schemes and work across the aisle to ensure and expand care, not rip it away.

Today I visited Bruce Randolph School to hear the stories of students and staff who depend on #DACA’s protections and whose futures now hang in the balance. Afterward, we took our message to the media: We must #DefendDACA. I have long encouraged local undocumented students, like the young men and women I met today, to sign up for the program because I believe in its promise. The stories and comments I heard from them further prove how critical it is to keep that promise, so that #DREAMers, numbering more than 17,000 in Colorado, have a chance to remain in the only country they have ever known and contribute to their communities. I pledge to continue supporting the Dream Act to fulfill DACA’s objectives.

With the Jewish new year approaching, it was lovely to celebrate the one-year anniversary of the JWI Young Women’s Leadership Network’s Denver Chapter with these wonderful young leaders. They’re bringing a fresh perspective to women’s empowerment. We discussed the many opportunities and challenges facing women in our community and across our country, and we renewed our commitment to upliftiting women through bold policy initiatives. I spoke about my work in Congress to achieve these goals sponsoring legislation such as the Paycheck Fairness Act, the Women’s Health Protection Act and a reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act.

As Senate Republicans try to fast-track #GrahamCassidy, their latest effort to dismantle important parts of the Affordable Care Act, it’s up to us to sound the alarm on this terrible bill. The #GOP is selling this plan as a kinder, gentler repeal of the #ACA, but don’t be fooled – its every bit as dangerous as previous repeal efforts, potentially throwing 32 million Americans off their health insurance in a decade and giving many states unchecked power to eliminate important consumer protections. This last-ditch effort before a September 30 deadline must be met with our strongest #resistance. I will continue leading the charge to #ProtectOurCare, and I hope you'll join me.

In 2009, Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price, then a Republican member of the House of Representatives, slammed government spending for planes as “fiscal responsibility run amuck.” So why has he reportedly spent $300,000 in taxpayer dollars on his own luxury jets during his tenure as head of the agency? This includes a private flight to Aspen a full 19 hours before his scheduled appearance at a conference. As a lifelong Coloradan, I’m pleased to welcome the Secretary to our state, but maybe he should practice what he preaches and fly commercial next time.

Today I joined my House Democratic colleagues in signing a  discharge petition to force a vote on the bipartisan #DreamAct. 800,000 #DREAMers nationwide, including more than 17,000 in Colorado alone, are counting on us to pass this critical legislation that lets them remain in the United States, the only home many of them have ever known. We won’t let Speaker Ryan drag his feet on this crisis any longer – we all have a moral obligation to #ProtectDREAMers.

Today I spoke out against a bill that would significantly undermine the Maternal, Infant, and Early Childhood Home Visiting Program. #MIECHV is a success story that has long enjoyed bipartisan support. Its evidence-based models are proven to deliver results for children and families in every state, but the bill before the House today would set MIECHV back. This partisan proposal’s damaging funding cuts would make it more difficult for MIECHV programs in Colorado and every state to continue effectively helping young families. It is truly a shame that House Republicans chose not to continue MIECHV’s bipartisan legacy today, but I’ll continue supporting ways to ensure a healthy and happy start for every child.

The latest Republican effort to dismantle the Affordable Care Act, #GrahamCassidy, has gone down in flames. Maybe now my colleagues across the aisle will finally turn their energies toward bipartisan efforts to improve the Affordable Care Act. I’ve been sharing proposals with them on how to do this for months. Americans have spoken out about how the #ACA is a lifeline; they want to mend it, not end it. We need to make sure that their concerns are not ignored, and that our health care system can offer all people the coverage and care that they need.

President Trump’s long-touted tax “plan” is now public. This outline offers no real details and is more of a political document. But what it does tell us is that the White House and members of the House GOP who negotiated this scheme in secret are planning another multi-trillion dollar giveaway to the wealthiest at the expense of working Americans. Instead of offering the American people a plan for real, job-creating tax reform, Republicans are pressing forward with a framework that would make the deficit balloon, and block critical domestic investments such as infrastructure, education and job training. This is no way to run our country – except, perhaps, into the ground.

President Trump has finally turned his attention briefly to the catastrophe in Puerto Rico, but he hasn’t done nearly enough with the tools at his disposal to help our fellow Americans there and in the U.S. Virgin Islands after the devastation of Hurricane Maria. People are starting to starve, many have no access to clean water, telecommunications infrastructure is in ruins and power outages are widespread, endangering those who need insulin and other life-saving medicine. Together with 145 fellow House Democrats, today I sent a letter imploring the president to do more to save lives in the region: augment the U.S. service members who are working on rescue and recovery by further mobilizing Department of Defense resources, including supporting local law enforcement in both places to end looting related to supply shortages, and appoint a senior general officer to work with FEMA to manage a joint response. These steps were taken in the wake of Hurricane Katrina. Are the 3.6 million American citizens in Puerto Rico and the USVI not worth a similar effort?

Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price says he won’t use charter flights while in office anymore and will pay back $51,887.31 for what he called “my seat” on the ones that he’s taken on the government dime so far. But that doesn’t even approach the cost of such luxuries, which has been estimated at more than $400,000. I’m looking into the exact bill and purpose for each such trip. The ones at issue have included a visit to an island in Georgia where he owns property at a resort. He has also reportedly used military aircraft in the past few months to get to Berlin, Geneva, Beijing, Ho Chi Minh City and Tokyo, often traveling with his wife, while accompanying staff have flown commercial – something his predecessors had only rarely done. There’s no question that some travel is necessary to the HHS Secretary’s job, but commercial flights at a reasonable cost should be the way to go.

The Senate is poised to vote to reconfirm Ajit Pai as Chairman of the FCC amid a flurry of ongoing controversies. Among them is evidence that he has given favorable treatment to Sinclair Broadcasting Group, a conservative media conglomerate. My Democratic colleagues and I on the Energy and Commerce committee are still waiting on a complete response to the letter we sent him demanding answers related to this controversy. Most troubling is his failure to provide the requested correspondence between his office and Sinclair representatives. We’ve seen enough instances where powerful administration officials have made ethically dubious moves. The Senate shouldn’t reconfirm Ajit Pai.

I spoke on the House floor against #HR36, sharing the story of a friend and colleague whose wife faced an excruciating personal decision late in her pregnancy because of a severe fetal anomaly that would affect the future of her family. This bill would have deprived her of that choice. It rips basic, constitutionally-protected rights from women and is needlessly cruel. I urge my colleagues across the aisle to respect #reprorights and #stopthebans.

This morning House Democrats united to honor the victims in #LasVegas, as well as all who have been killed in senseless mass shootings, and to send a message to our Republican colleagues: Enough is enough. Americans are desperate for sensible gun-safety legislation, and we can’t afford inaction. In attendance was my good friend and former congressional colleague, Gabrielle Giffords, who has devoted her life to this cause since surviving a shooting that left her with a severe brain injury. Her bravery, passion and dedication, and those of countless other victims, inspire us to never stop fighting until we pass smart legislation that keeps guns out of the hands of those who wish to use them for grave harm.

The Energy and Commerce Committee has approved the bipartisan Protecting Access to Diabetes Supplies Act (H.R. 3271). Every day, sometimes several times a day, seniors and other people with diabetes use test strips in glucose monitors to ensure appropriate insulin dosing. If they don’t get their dosage right, it jeopardizes their health. I introduced this bill together with Republican Tom Reed of New York, my co-chair in the Congressional Diabetes, and Caucus vice-chair Susan Brooks (R-IN) because it’s crucial to resolve ongoing issues that hamper many Americans’ access to quality diabetes test strips and supplies via Medicare’s National Mail Order Program. Our bill would streamline this process and ensure that the 11 million Americans on Medicare who have diabetes are able to get the test results they need to live healthy lives.

The entire Colorado congressional delegation joined me in sending a letter to Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos urging the tech giant to build its second headquarters in the Centennial State. The nine of us, representing the House and the Senate on both sides of the political aisle, don’t always see eye-to-eye – but we can all agree that Colorado is a great place to do business and an ideal location for this ambitious economic investment that could create more than 50,000 new jobs. Colorado’s exemplary infrastructure, public lands, educational institutions and fiscal management have created an enviable quality of life and have already encouraged Amazon to expand existing operations here. Colorado is ready for #HQ2.

I’ve been engaged in this struggle for a long time, and have seen it up close and quite personal. We must do everything within our power to avoid one more such attack. A report of further efforts by President Trump and his administration to sabotage the Affordable Care Act, this time in Iowa. According to The Washington Post, officials in the Hawkeye State sought federal permission to shore up their ailing health-insurance marketplace. President Trump allegedly heard of this request and personally intervened by calling the federal director to tell him to deny the request, and that’s what happened. The Trump administration has neglected enrollment efforts in other states such as Ohio, Oklahoma and  Mississippi. It appears President Trump won’t accept the fact that #ACA remains law of the land – and if he can’t manage to get it repealed, he’ll undermine it. Polls show most Americans support the #ACA and want to see it improved, not dismantled. Why won’t the President respect that?

President Trump’s assault on women’s health continues: He now wants to let employers discriminate against women who choose to use birth control. Today his administration announced an interim final rule that that would allow any employer to be exempt from the requirement to provide health insurance that includes contraception. As a result, many women will be forced to pay the full cost of their birth control, which costs an average $225 per year, which is out of reach for many people. Under the Affordable Care Act, insurers are required to cover birth control at no cost. We must remind the President that birth control is health care, plain and simple, and his decision could rip this essential aspect of care from tens of millions of women. As Co-Chair of the Congressional pro Choice Caucus, I will continue opposing these regressive policies and work to cement the #reprorights gained through the #ACA.  #HandsOffMyBC.

Although we have come far in understanding mental illness, we must continue working to reduce stigma and help people better manage their conditions. 21st Century Cures, my biomedical research bill that became law last December, allocated additional funding for research and programs that tackle mental health on many fronts. A sound mind is just as important as a healthy body, and I’ll continue working to ensure this for all.

On #NationalComingOutDay, I stand with the millions of people across America and around the world who have publicly embraced their #LGBTQ identity or plan to make that choice today. Every person who comes out further affirms this group’s visibility and right to equality and acceptance. As a founding member of the LGBT Equality Caucus, I will continue working to advance policies that build upon existing progress and fighting hard against the current administration’s discriminatory rollbacks.

As co-chairs of the Congressional Privacy Caucus, Rep. Joe Barton (R-TX) and I sent a letter to Equifax Interim CEO Paulino do Rego Barros Jr. requesting more information on any new programs or policies that his company plans to implement after the historic data breach that compromised 145 million people’s files. While there is no national standard for the types of remedies that should be offered to those whose data has been compromised, we believe services previously offered to identity theft victims, such as credit and financial monitoring, dark web monitoring and stolen funds reimbursement, need to be considered. We await a thorough response.

The horrific massacre in #LasVegas last week highlighted yet again our country’s need for comprehensive #gunsafety legislation, and I’ve cosponsored the Keep Americans Safe Act to help achieve this goal. Our bill prohibits  the transfer, importation or possession of magazines that are able to hold more than 10 rounds of ammunition. Too many civilians have accessed high-capacity, military-grade weapons to commit grave harm. We can ensure every American’s Second Amendment rights while also creating common-sense safeguards to protect innocent lives, and this legislation is one such measure that I’m honored to support.

I joined fellow Democratic leaders on the Energy and Commerce Committee in sending a letter to Acting Health and Human Services Secretary Eric Hargan, asking him about the sources of the specious claim used to justify gutting the #ACA #birthcontrol mandate and denying women access to birth control coverage. We have very serious concerns about this development, which will allow many more employers to deny coverage for this essential element of women’s health. We also asked how women who lose coverage will be able to get care if the Administration continues to undermine Medicaid and Title X.

Every woman has a right to affordable contraception, and President Trump’s ongoing efforts to rip this essential aspect of care from millions through new anti-choice rules is incredibly dangerous. As co-chair of the Pro Choice Caucus, I’m working to push back, which is why I have joined my congressional colleagues Rep. Louise Slaughter, Rep. Judy Chu and Rep. Lois Frankel in introducing the Protect Access to Birth Control Act. Our bill would block two Interim Final Rules issued this month that allow employers to be exempt from #ACA requirements to cover #birthcontrol and other forms of contraception without cost-sharing. These personal health care decisions shouldn’t be subject to an objection from a boss, school or insurance company. Birth Control is health care, plain and simple, which is why it’s critical our bill becomes law.

Last week, President Trump said that his administration deserves a “10” for its response to hurricane #Maria’s devastation in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Given that most residents still don’t have power, nearly a million Americans lack access to safe and reliable drinking water, and endless reports of subsistence living for many, I find that statement to be breathtaking. While I commend the valiant efforts of the many relief workers and volunteers, it’s clear our government could and should be doing much more. The Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee, where I serve as Ranking Member, today held the first of what I hope are many hearings examining the federal government’s response to the 2017 hurricane season. I encourage further hearings on this crisis and official congressional visits to these devastated areas so my colleagues can fully comprehend the dire need for comprehensive relief and rebuilding efforts for our fellow Americans.

Today's Energy and Commerce hearing focused on federal efforts to combat the #opioid epidemic. I questioned a panel of expert witnesses on the government’s successes and failures to date in responding effectively. The 21st Century Cures Act, my biomedical research bill that became law last December, allocated $1 billion to support state prevention programs. Congress must be sure to extend this funding to pave the way for similar programs, because efforts tailored to local and regional needs are critical to treating and preventing opioid addiction.

Today I led my colleagues in speaking out against President Trump’s discriminatory rules that let employers opt out of covering birth control for their employees, an #ACA provision that has helped millions of women. Joined by House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi, my Pro-Choice Caucus co-chair Louise Slaughter, fellow House members committed to women’s health, and other stakeholders, we all sent a clear message: Birth Control is Health Care. Access to it should not be determined by someone’s boss. It’s 2017 – the time to litigate these basic reproductive rights has long passed. That’s why 188 members of Congress joined me in sending a letter today to the Trump administration condemning these actions. In addition, I sponsored the Protect Access to Birth Control Act (H.R. 4082), which would block these rules

President Trump’s #birthcontrol rules send a dangerous message to women that bosses should have the final say over personal #reprohealth decisions. No way. Our letter to the administration and our legislation, The Protect Access to Birth Control Act, send an even clearer message: It’s none of your bosses’ business.

President Donald J. Trump’s just-announced plan to address #opioid abuse is far from sufficient – starting with funding for the effort. The president’s declaration falls far short, and does not deliver on his promise to make fighting the opioid epidemic a top priority. Our state and local officials on the front lines of this fight have been very clear: They need more funding. The one billion dollars we provided in the 21st Century Cures Act was badly needed and a step in the right direction. But we must commit to devoting more funding and extending these vital dollars beyond 2018. As a senior member of the Energy and Commerce Committee and a lifelong resident of a state that is wrestling with this epidemic, I will continue urging the President and Congress to get serious about ending opioid abuse.

Tomorrow is National Prescription Drug #TakeBackDay, an annual nationwide initiative to safely dispose of unused or expired prescription medication at locations across the country. The 2015 National Survey on Drug Use and Health found 6.4 million Americans abused controlled prescription drugs, and many obtained them from the medicine cabinets of family members and friends. I encourage everyone to take this small step to help solve the big problem of drug and #opioid abuse. Click on the link in the first comment to learn more and to find a collection site near you.

This #DiabetesAwarenessMonth, we honor the millions of diabetics across America and around the world. Although the diagnosis is life-changing and often frightening, I’m consistently inspired by those who haven’t let diabetes stop them from living healthy and fulfilling lives, including my daughter. As co-chair of the Diabetes Caucus, I’m working to ensure this peace of mind for everybody with the condition through a number of initiatives, including our ongoing inquiry into the rising cost of insulin. I’m fighting for a future without diabetes, but we must also work to better treat and prevent it today.

Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke is planning to nearly double or triple entrance fees to 17 of America’s most treasured national parks, including Colorado’s Rocky Mountain National Park. This step would likely deter millions of American families from visiting these gems. Eighty-nine colleagues and I sent a letter to Secretary Zinke today asking him to abandon his plan. The national parks are an integral part of our country’s shared history and culture. We should be making it easier for all to enjoy these natural wonders, through efforts such as my bill to allow fourth graders free entrance into these parks. Public lands belong to everyone, not the privileged few.

Today the Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee, on which I serve as ranking member, held a hearing on the security of bioresearch labs, where many dangerous pathogens are housed. The safe handling of select agents has been an issue of long-standing concern to  our committee. We need to ensure that labs are secure and handling this material properly so that researchers and the public are protected. If not,  something very, very bad will happen unless the CDC acts. We must develop better rules, standards and inter-agency cooperation to ensure Americans can rest easy knowing they are safe from deadly pathogens, and I urge our committee to hold more hearings to help achieve the goal of total safety and security.

Congressional Republicans have finally released their much-anticipated #tax plan after assuring the American people for months of its supposed merits. Their grand unveiling, however, only reveals a one-sided, ill-conceived partisan effort. The bill does little for the middle class while rewarding the wealthy, slashing the corporate tax rate and taxes for the one percent. Rather than trying to ram through this one-sided scam, a behemoth of more than 400 pages written behind closed doors that is reportedly being rushed to a vote before Thanksgiving, Republicans should work in good faith with Democrats on real and meaningful tax reform, because this isn’t it.

Only the 115th Congress could find a way to politicize #CHIP, the Children’s Health Insurance Program. As one of its original authors, I care deeply about this lifeline for vulnerable children and families, which has long enjoyed bipartisan support. But this year, Republicans missed the September 30th deadline to extend CHIP’s funding. And now they’ve put a bill forward extending CHIP but also cutting funds for the Affordable Care Act, which could rip coverage away from 668,000 people. Republicans are presenting a false choice. We can save and even strengthen CHIP without gutting the #ACA, and I certainly won’t reward their bad governance represented in this legislation. That’s why, difficult as it was, I voted no.

I’ve just introduced the Tobacco to 21 Act, which prohibits the sale of tobacco products to anybody under age 21. Smoking is a deadly, addictive habit that can harm human health even in limited amounts. Why on earth would we wish to expose our young people to its dangers? It is our moral obligation to ensure that the law does not favor the tobacco industry over the health and safety of our nation’s youth. This bill, which has also been introduced by colleagues in the Senate, would go a long way to keeping carcinogens out of young people’s hands – and throats, and lungs.

Rep. Reed and I are open to embracing a wide variety of potential solutions if they’re workable. The millions of Americans with diabetes and prediabetes are counting on it.

Republicans in the House and Senate are forging ahead recklessly with their dangerous #TaxScam. Not only will this bill raise taxes on millions of middle class families, it also ransacks the budgets of Medicare and Medicaid, all to pay for tax breaks to corporations and the ultra-wealthy. Republicans have used their first year of total control in Washington to attempt to make changes that will harm average Americans, including their failed attempts to repeal #ACA. I join fellow Democrats in fighting against this damaging agenda and offering #ABetterDeal to every American.

Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands are still suffering widespread power outages, shortages of basic necessities and overwhelmed health facilities due to recent hurricane damage. The response of federal disaster agencies has fallen shamefully short. However, storms that hit Florida and Texas seemed to receive more federal attention than those affecting fellow Americans in these overseas territories. At an Environment Subcommittee hearing,  I questioned a panel of expert witnesses, including Environmental Protection Agency Regional Administrators Peter Lopez and Trey Glenn, in the hopes of finding out why and how. Their incomplete answers to my questions are very concerning. While I commend the men and women in the region who have worked tirelessly to rescue and rebuild in all disaster areas, it appears that to me that relief efforts in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands were not given the same level of attention as other places.

Students and doctors supporting women’s reproductive rights held #HandsOffMyBC rallies in support of birth control across the United States today, including in Denver. Colleagues in the Pro-Choice Caucus, where I serve as co-chair, joined me at the event in DC. We’re not letting President Trump or congressional Republicans off the hook for their ongoing efforts to rip  #contraception from millions of women through recently-issued rules allowing employers to opt out of offering health insurance to cover it. Depriving women of this coverage is a danger to their health and economic well-being. This is 2017! It’s astonishing to think that it’s even necessary to take such a stand, but the threat is very real. We’re saying loud and clear: Birth control IS health care.

We’ve heard Republicans sing the praises of tax cuts for the wealthy and “trickle-down economics” for decades. But in that time, our nation has become increasingly unequal, with the ultra-rich profiting disproportionately from changes to tax law while the middle class suffers. The latest #GOPTaxScam before the House of Representatives today is no different in that respect, but its effects could be the most damaging yet. That’s why I’m fighting to ensure that it never becomes law.

#HappyThanksgiving to my fellow Coloradans and all Americans. On this special holiday, let's take the time to give thanks for all of life's blessings that unite us -- family, friends, fulfillment and more. Wishing you and yours a wonderful day.

Thanks to Volunteers of America Colorado and City Harvest Food Bank for your tireless efforts to assist Coloradans in need. I’ll continue working in Congress to support the volunteer services and organizations that uplift our community, and countless others across America.

Republicans’ failure to extend the Children's Health Insurance Program is now hitting home. The funding authorization for this critical program expired on October 1; in Colorado, where #CHIP funding will run out by the end of January, families are already receiving letters warning them amid this holiday season that their kids’ coverage could soon be cancelled. On MSNBC this evening, I spoke with Ari Melber about the critical need to renew CHIP, which had long been a bipartisan priority until this year. As one of the creators of this program, protecting it is personal, and I will work hard to save it from #GOP obstruction.

#21stCenturyCures, my biomedical research bill that became law last December, will revolutionize our country’s search for treatment and cures of vexing diseases for years to come. I’m proud that the Energy and Commerce Committee recognized what these reforms could do, and today, a year after the bill’s passage in the House, the same committee is reflecting on its initial successes and future potential to save millions of lives. This is only a beginning;  I believe this groundbreaking law will be the catalyst for a new generation of #cures

Residents of Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands are still reeling from the devastation of hurricane Maria, and after holding hearings on recovery and rebuilding efforts, I saw the results up close with some of my Democratic and Republican colleagues on the Energy and Commerce Committee this weekend. Critical infrastructure such as bridges and power plants remain in stark disrepair months after the hurricane made landfall. Local officials, many of whom I had the pleasure of meeting, should be commended for their efforts to begin rebuilding, but it's clear these U.S. territories continue to need all of the support and power our federal government can provide. I will keep working to supply this vital aid. Our fellow Americans will not be forgotten.

As the Supreme Court prepared to hear oral arguments in the #MasterpieceCakeshop case this morning, I spoke in support of the respondents, Charlie Craig and David Mullins. In 2012, this couple were denied service by Masterpiece Cakeshop in Lakewood, Colorado, simply because they are gay and were planning their wedding festivities. I'm proud that these men took their fight for full #equality to the highest court in the land through a case that affects protections not only for #LGBTQ, but for many other groups of Americans as well. Last month, I joined more than 200 members of Congress in signing an amicus brief supporting their case. This fight is vital. We can't go back to the days when businesses could openly discriminate against customers; the courts have ruled against that time and time again. Our communities and our country must be #OpenToAll.

After speaking at a rally on their behalf, I was honored to meet my constituents Charlie Craig and David Mullins, who are at the heart of the #MasterpieceCakeshop case. After this Lakewood, Colorado, bakery denied them service due to their sexual orientation, they fought back, winning court victories that brought them before the highest court in the land today. I’m proud to represent these men who are helping ensure that businesses in our community and across America are #OpenToAll.

Hurricane recovery efforts in #PuertoRico and #USVI are coming along, but still have a long way to go. I saw the result up-close on a bipartisan congressional visit this past weekend and jotted down a few thoughts together with one of my Republican colleagues on the House Energy and Commerce Committee, Rep. Fred Upton of Michigan. While the news cycle has sadly pushed this storm-ravaged region out of the spotlight, we haven’t forgotten about the critical need to help the residents still struggling to rebuild their lives and homes. Our main takeaway is that is that the federal government’s work to help our fellow Americans in these island territories needs to be sustained for months – or even years to come. I’ll work to achieve this and to ensure these citizens are not forgotten.

It’s shameful that Republicans are responding to two of the worst mass shootings in recent U.S. history with #HR38. EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt recently spent nearly $25,000 in taxpayer funds on an addition to his new office: a fancy soundproof booth that’s normally used to protect government secrets. At a hearing of the Subcommittee on the Environment today, I asked him why this pricey purchase was made, particularly when the agency faces a steep cut of around 30% in President Trump’s budget. It’s concerning that he couldn’t say how often it’s used, and was fuzzy on other details. Serving on the Environment Subcommittee helps me hold this administration accountable for its use of federal resources; in many ways, they’re not holding themselves accountable.

Today I led nearly 100 of my congressional colleagues in sending a letter to House and Senate leadership on both sides of the aisle urging Congress to responsibly extend funding for the Children’s Health Insurance Program, which was allowed to lapse September 30.  As things stand now, CHIP funds in Colorado will run out by the end of January, and families are starting to receive notices about that amid the holiday season. As one of CHIP’s co-authors, I am especially attuned to this travesty; the program is a  lifeline that has enjoyed bipartisan support for years, but Republicans have dangerously politicized it by passing a bill to extend it at the expense of other programs such as the #ACA and #Medicaid. #CHIP is certainly not a bargaining tool for the millions of children enrolled, including the nearly 23,000 in Colorado who stand to lose their coverage in less than two months. I am making it a top priority in the busy year-end legislative session because families can’t afford to wait.

One year ago this week, President Obama signed #21stCenturyCures into law, setting the stage for a biomedical revolution. Our bill was the culmination of lots of hard work, bipartisan cooperation and substantive meetings with knowledgeable stakeholders. A year later, #cures is already living up to its promise through its acceleration of key medical research projects – including the #cancermoonshot, the BRAIN Initiative and more – that will save millions of lives.

The EPA Inspector General’s decision to investigate Administrator Scott Pruitt’s questionable purchase of a $25,000 fancy soundproof booth for his new office is a necessary first step in holding him accountable. I requested this investigation months ago and asked Pruitt to explain the purchase last week at a hearing of the Environment Subcommittee. This vital agency faces a 30% cut from President Trump’s proposed budget, making it even more critical to determine whether Mr. Pruitt is a responsible steward of limited taxpayer funds.

During last year’s passage of #21stCenturyCures, articles chronicling its journey to becoming law were refreshingly free of partisan bickering and name-calling. That’s because our biomedical research bill was a truly bipartisan effort, passed with overwhelming support from both sides of the aisle. As we celebrate the law’s first birthday today, I’m thankful that my Democratic and Republican colleagues have remained committed to ensuring its success. In a divisive year, #cures reminds us that saving lives is a goal we all share.

#21stCenturyCures began as a simple idea that became a biomedical revolution. In this video commemorating its first birthday, Congressman Fred Upton and I reflect on the law’s historic passage and remarkable progress in helping find #cures for vexing diseases. This is only the beginning. When we come together to achieve a shared goal, we can make life better for millions.

Over the past six months, I’ve worked with Congressman Tom Reed (R-NY), my Diabetes Caucus co-chair, to determine the causes of the rising price of #insulin. People with diabetes depend on this life-saving drug, but it is becoming out of reach for far too many, perhaps due to needless cost increases along the complicated supply chain that brings it to market. At a hearing of the Health Subcommittee on drug pricing, I asked witnesses representing pharmaceutical companies, pharmacy benefit managers and insurers if they would commit to sharing information with us about this supply chain. Having this information, among other knowledge, will ensure our inquiry gets to the root causes of sky-high insulin prices, which will help Congress determine the best ways to lower them.

Today, 118 members of Congress sent a letter to FCC Chairman Ajit Pai urging him to cancel this week’s planned vote to gut Title II #NetNeutrality protections. Net Neutrality is vital to ensuring a free open internet, protecting freedom of speech, economic opportunity and more. We must not let the FCC sell these rights to the highest bidder. #DefendNetNeutrality

I want to thank the many Coloradans who have expressed on social media and in calls to my office the importance of #NetNeutrality. I have opposed all along the FCC’s efforts to roll back these protections, including sending a letter yesterday to Chairman Pai urging him to cancel today’s vote. He didn’t listen. The agency just voted to gut Net Neutrality, but this isn’t the end of our fight. We will continue working to ensure an open internet that protects free speech and promotes economic opportunity for all. This is a setback, but not a defeat.
